These sensing knowledge feeders don’t require a significant amount of cognition to deliver effective results. Ants emit pheromones that enhance their collective behavior by making each individual ant a sensor of the environment around them. This optimizes routes used for the scouting of food with remarkable accuracy. Interestingly, ants don’t just optimize the search direction. They also optimize the amount of “ant resources” deployed in the search, to ensure their collective energy is used correctly at the right time. Some do so by simply modulating the speed of exit from the anthill, achieved by sensing the speed of incoming ants. Returning ants bump into those who are ready to exit. The faster the rate of return (signaling more food available, because it took less time to find it) the more ants are sent out. A bee’s “dance” serves a similar purpose.

Use case: Model behaviours and interventions for crisis planning
Description: During and following a crisis situation, decision making at both the individual and the collective level changes rapidly due to the severe disruption caused to people’s daily lives. To manage and respond to a crisis effectively, and to aid humanitarian efforts during a crisis, it is important to understand and anticipate how different groups and individuals will react  n a spatially and temporally precise way. Challenges in understanding people’s behaviour during a crisis are often compounded by a lack of spatial data in less developed countries. Even in cases where spatial data is available, it often lags behind what has changed on-the-ground – for instance when the physical landscape has altered due to a natural disaster. What is the CCI  olution? This case study outlines a prototype of an agent-based model (ABM) integrating GIS, crowdsourced geographic information and other sources of publicly available data, which seeks to explore how aid might be distributed to better support affected communities. The model uses the devastating 2010 earthquake in Haiti which is estimated to have killed 230,000 people and  eft more than 1.6 million people homeless. The model explores how affected communities search for food following an earthquake and allows the user to explore different scenario options for aid distribution. How is it being done? The model uses a diverse range of crowdsourced data including geographic information about population density, relative level of devastation, existing transportation networks, location of aid centres, and environmental parameters. The researchers used publicly available (open) data to estimate population density and OpenStreetMap data. The simulation produces a map showing the movement of individuals throughout the environment and the spread of information about aid (e.g. food) availability, as well as graphs tracking how individual agents use ifferent aid centres over time. Over time more and more agents become aware of their nearest food distribution point as well as other distribution points, as information spreads throughout the system. Agents then evaluate if it is worthwhile for them to go and get food. They do this by planning the shortest path to the food via the road network.  (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Use deliberative democracy polling to investigate better political decision-making
Description: To practice democracy at its purest, in a time of political polarization, an experiment called America in One Room, organized by Helena magazine in collaboration with Stanford Univeristy, brought together the most representative sample of the electorate in U.S. history. A stratified random sample of 523 registered voters, recruited by NORC at the University of Chicago, was identified out of millions of Americans through a rigorous scientific process in order to represent the political, cultural, and demographic diversity of the American electorate. Helena brought each American to a single location — a resort in Dallas, Texas. For four days, the delegates participated in an unprecedented deliberation on the critical issues facing the United States. In a process called “deliberative democracy polling”, the 523 participants began by taking an in-depth questionnaire, stating their views on five key issue areas identified in earlier polling as most vital to the 2020 presidential election. The group was then given a 60-page briefing document, prepared and vetted by a distinguished group of policy experts from across the political spectrum. The document was balanced with arguments for and against specific policy proposals across the five issue areas. The group was then given a 60-page briefing document, prepared and vetted by a distinguished group of policy experts from across the political spectrum. The document was balanced with arguments for and against specific policy proposals across the five issue areas. During the ensuing 4 days, the America in One Room group vigorously and respectfully deliberated on these polarizing issues with one another. Their discussions took place in two formats: moderated, representative small group settings and evening plenary sessions, where the group convened as a single unit to ask live questions to 2020 presidential candidates and a bipartisan selection of experts and political figures ranging from the former White House Chief of Staff and former leaders of the National Security Council, Congressional Budget Office and White Economic Policy advisory. At the end of the final day, the group took the original questionnaire again. The outcome was a landmark data set that represented the “will of the people” — what Americans think about values, candidates, and policy issues when given the chance to think deeply, engage with different opinions, and deliberate in a fact-rich and respectful environment.

Contagion is the spread of a virus in a network of people. Curbing it requires isolation of network spreaders. To do so, South Korea implemented network sensors (pervasive testing), and by tracing back the networks of the infected was able to contain the spread. Compare that with Italy, which – thanks to the signal from Asia - had a head start in sensing the threat. Italy started testing early, though not at as pervasively as South Korea. But the actual response of both authorities and the public was too slow and uncoordinated to prevent the virus from spreading in cross-generational households and in the dense social fabric of Italian society. Neither security rules (prohibiting gatherings and tracking spreaders) nor social norms changed fast enough. The collective response was a democratic one without executive powers to coerce the collective. Each person chose how to behave for too long, and then it was too late to stop the spread. After a few weeks, Italy’s fatalities overtook China’s, a country whose population is fifty times larger. It is worth mentioning that Italy’s lesson still didn’t help the largely hierarchical decision-making in the US, UK and Brazil, which ended up witnessing devastating consequences.

Description: The ubiquity of sensors, combined with the availability of machine learning and other computationally sophisticated methods and infrastructure, is also bound to change the field of economics. GDP measurement is a hierarchical effort, lacks granularity and speed, and is subject to significant manual intervention. Information like restaurant booking OpenTable can help surface early signals to sense changing conditions and inform trend estimates in ways that were previously impossible.

Use case: Use decentralized autonomous organizations to produce media
Description: Forefront, Bankless, and DarkStar are Media DAOs. These entities produce public content, often collaboratively. Rewards from that content are shared across the group, while governance is also a communal affair. Stakeholders may help decide on topics to cover as well as managing resourcing. (Source: The Generalist)

Use case: Use decentralized autonomous organizations to support artists
Description: Creator DAOs center themselves around an individual. Just like some fan clubs give an influencer’s most passionate supporters opportunities for consumption and interaction, DAOs have the capacity to do the same. Beyond pure fandom, stakeholders can also actively contribute or work for an organization that supports the creators for whom they are most enthusiastic. A number of creators adopt “social tokens” through products like Roll, which lay the groundwork for true Creator DAOs. Early movers include Leaving Records and Personal Corner.(Source: The Generalist)

Use case: Use decentralized autonomous organizations to produce media
Description: PubDAO creates and promotes media articles related to crypto, through a blockchain-based DAO (decentralized autonomous organization). They describe themselves as "a decentralized Associated Press". News are debated initially in a Discord channel, but PubDAO is expected to use extensively a $PUB token to decide of allocation of resources.

Use case: Use crypto infrastructure for creative communities
Description: Rally.IO helps creators and their fans become independent from existing creator-economy platforms (e.g., Substack) by enabling the minting and exchange of individual crypto coins in their individual community.

Use case: Use DAO to purchase a rare good
Description: Decentralized autonomous organization created to tokenize the purchase of the original US Constitution document at a public Sotheby auction

labDAO members could build data and resource management software, in return for token ownership. The DAO interacts with physical labs (existing or new) by paying to run experiments and providing data or materials to the token holders who funded the work. Data can be managed in an electronic lab notebook (ELN) on chain, using NFT datasets, for later licensing or use by third parties. New labs can join the DAO to earn tokens for their services or to support scientific progress by providing their methods at cost. Source: arye.substack.com/p/building-a-labdao-for-web3-biotech

Use case: Enable citizens to increase transparency, accountability, and community effectiveness
Description: www.mysociety.org is an NGO based in the UK whose technology is used in dozens of countries, to enable citizens so they can keep their institutions more accountable and informed. They do so by improving the user experience in doing things that democratic institutions are mandated to do, but often don't make it easy to happen - such as alerting public authorities or public officials about local problems, or requesting information from them.

Use case: Authenticate personally-identifiable credentials on blockchain technology
Description: In Web3, people won't need a platform to authenticate them. Their identity and credentials could be stored in web3 technology, likely on blockchain, and would travel with them across the web. Violet aims to authenticate off-chain, personally identifiable information on-chain.

Use case: Decentralize finance for distribute energy trading
Description: Grid singularity is building an energy exchange that provides an integrity solution in a major shift away from a traditional, centralized model of the energy market. If it works, it has the power to make energy markets more efficient and decentralized with many powerful application scenarios. Grid Singularity exchange lets your energy assets trade directly. Your home becomes an energy trader in an inclusive, fair market, unlocking your economic, social and environmental benefits. Blockchain based.

Use case: Distribute the cost and opportunity of drug development
Description: Blockchain based, MRNASwap aims at creating a more liquid and open market for reducing healthcare development costs. Fee-Sharing NFT (FSN) recoups the R&D cost of specific drug assets for drug developers with uncapped real-time streaming payout. Efficacy Risk Swaps are the crypto counterpart of credit default swap (CDS) to neutralize drug efficacy risk. By holding ERS, healthcare investors and drug developers can insure against clinical trial failures.

Use case: Use Blockchain to enable ride hailing
Description: India based startup Drife uses a blockchain based platform to disrupt established platforms and give more power to local entrepreneurs (franchisees and drivers), by rebuilding some of the collaboration and control functionality on web3 native infrastructure (DAO and related decentralized apps - DApps)

Use case: Set up a crypto fund beside traditional VC investments
Description: In 2021, selling cryptographic, blockchain based tokens becoming a more popular way to fund new enterprises. Venture capital firm A16z has set up a dedicated fund to buy promising startups' tokens

Use case: Fund medical research through a DAO
Description: PsyDAO is forming a decentralised organisation (DAO) with the goal of funding research at the intersection of psychedelics and mental health.

Use case: Weaken Russia's tech production through supply-chain sanctions
Description: In the immediate aftermath of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the US Government enforced sanctions aimed at preventing the sale to Russia of any advanced technology produced anywhere in the world using US-made components. The network effects of this economic retaliation impacts the entire supply chain of advanced technology good for business-to-business use.

Use case: Match students with a marketplace of tutors
Description: Developer of an online learning application designed to connect students with teachers worldwide for individual or group tutoring sessions. The company's application uses artificial intelligence to support tutor selection and onboarding processes and also offers a free social homework chat, enabling students to access a range of tutoring subscription packages and discuss their questions with others in an easy and safe environment.

The F-35 has been designed to enable real-time collaboration between aircraft and other equipement engaged in a mission, hence generating more-intelligent response thanks to the collective sensing and decision-making.

Use case: Attract and distribute resources for defense
Description: UkraineDAO is a funding and routing decentralized autonomous organization set up by activists groups to support Ukraine's military and civilians during the Russian invasion in 2022

Jakarta has seen a radical transformation of its public transport since 2010, which has greatly improved traffic conditions. Key leverage points in this change have been (a) making the transport modes more interoperable (e.g. through integrated maps and payments) and (b) shifting incentives for private transportation providers from fee-per-passenger to fee-per-kilometer which made driving safer. Additionally, cycling lanes were improved, making the system more holistically usable.

Use case: Launch crowdsourced cyberattacks during military conflict
Description: During the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022, a reported 300,000 global and self-organized non-combatants supported cyberattacks on Russian IT infrastructure.

Use case: Pool solar power generation through web3
Description: India based Sunday Grids helps people who can't install solar on their roof participate in solar panel deployments that take place in more conducive places (such as industrial roofs). The contributions are tokenized through blockchain and the respective returns accrue to the token holders which can then use them offset power bills. A dashboard provides a continuous stream of information about the yield of the facilities installed.

Use case: Connect science to funding in a decentralized manner
Description: Molecule is creating collaborative ecosystems, where stakeholders in drug development can work together to expedite the process of bringing novel therapeutics to patients. They are connecting leading researchers to funding by turning intellectual property and its development into a liquid and easily investable asset.

Use case: Improving human's skills by playing against AI
Description: Research indicates that professional Go players playing against AI improved their games, especially if they were younger and more open to new strategies. https://hyokang.com/assets/pdf/CKKK-AI-Go.pdf

Use case: Improve human performance through crowdsourced AR (concept)
Description: A builder could be guided on his work by a more-experience, perhaps even retired, remote colleague who is working from home: both use augmented reality goggles to see what each other sees. 4G and certainly 5G make the transmission of data fast and detailed. This model can be applied to any field where an in-field operator may lack the skills to deal with unusual circumstances, while a remote pool of experts can serve multiple in-field operators. Applications can range from remote healthcare through paramedics and first responders, to installation of new climate-neutral energy assets such solar panels or insulation, to deployment of new agricultural and forestry methods.

Use case: Using AI and collective behavior to drive financial alpha
Description: Renaissance's hedge fund is one of the most succesful financial players today. Their Medallion fund trades through algorithms that look at the patterns of reaction of human traders, and it is especially strong in times when humans panic. The algorithms' success shows that humans are most predictable in moments of panic, but financial markets do revert to the mean at some point. In the meantime, trading through that volatility could be very profitable, when done by machines that second guess the short term reactions of traders, and the longer term trend beyond that noise.

Use case: Using web3 to build scientists' reputation
Description: Currently, scientists’ reputations — and as a result their ability to secure funding — are tied to publishing metrics. With blockchain technology, scientists could earn NFTs for doing other activities that research communities deem valuable, such as peer review, training and mentoring, and sharing data openly. NFT collections could act as a verifiable digital reputation for contributions, further incentivizing such behaviors. Scientists and groups of individuals with a shared wallet, such as a decentralized lab, could build reputation this way. Source: Sarah Hamburg.

Use case: Enhance demand flexibility and climate resilience in urban areas
Description: Collective intelligence is applied to manage the demand response among buildings. CI improves the autonomy in absorbing shocks without the need for upgrading the central control. Source: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apenergy.2020.116106

J-Ventures is a community-driven global venture capital fund of top investors, executives and founders. Based in Silicon Valley, it operates as a collaborative community of leaders with shared values and a strong network of connected capital. They call themselves a "capitalist kibbutz".
Cindicator uses superforecasters and machine learning to predict volatile crypto assets and guide trades.

Use case: Verify crowdsourced imagery by looking at the sun's shade
Description: Open source intelligence (OSINT) is increasingly used in the near-real-time analysis of the development of conflicts. Verifying the authenticity of imagery is a critical step in process. One way to do that is to use apps like SunCalc calculate the length of shades on ground at the alleged time of an event, and compare it with what's in the crowdsourced imagery.

Use case: Improving quality and quantity of life
Description: Blue Zones (Okinawa, Loma Linda, Sardinia's Ogliastra etc) are areas where people live longer and healtier than what would be expected from the analysis of standard socioeconomic parameters. Those regions are distinctive because of their collective care traits, in addition to sustainable habits and type of food.

Use case: Increase the effectiveness of autonomous devices
Description: Swarms of robots, using specific swarm-intelligence algorithms, are increasingly considered as a solution for patrolling or intervening in challenging areas - from military to environmental disasters to space mining, to more common agricultural yield improvement. For instance, Korean Air has implemented a solution for airplane maintenance checks that involves a small number of drones operating together around the aircraft, resulting in reduction of time per inspection.

Use case: Accelerate climate technology transition by committing prices for future transactions
Description: Frontier is an advance market commitment to buy an initial $925M of permanent carbon removal between 2022 and 2030, hence bringing forward a market incentive to providers of solutions. It’s funded by Stripe (who also owns it), Alphabet, Shopify, Meta, McKinsey, and tens of thousands of businesses using Stripe Climate. Frontier is an advance market commitment (AMC) that aims to accelerate the development of carbon removal technologies by guaranteeing future demand for them. The goal is to send a strong demand signal to researchers, entrepreneurs, and investors that there is a growing market for these technologies. Importantly, Frontier aims to help create net new carbon removal supply rather than compete over what exists today. In practice, its team of technical and commercial experts facilitates purchases from high-potential carbon removal companies on behalf of buyers.

Blockchain based Miamicoins is an example of the possibility to generate liquidity for local markets, enabling authorities, businesses and citizens to use them to address their specific needs. Miamicoins' smart contract enabled the community to allocate resources toward fighting the impact of climate change on Miami, among others. Kenya's Sarafu is an example of local currency serving 50,000 users.

Use case: Enable central banks to issue cryptocurrencies
Description: Crypto based digital currencies are central bank's cryptocurrencies. They are an effort to modernize the monetary system, but also come with the risk of adding public control in nondemocratic ways.

Blockchain DeFi (decentralized finance) includes decentralized exchanges (DEX) where market participants trade directly with each other without the need of a central clearinghouse (e.g. the New York Exchange). When doing so, they rely on Automated Market Making (AMM) that is an algorithm that provides the liquidity for buy / sell positions without the need of physical market makers.
Composer is a platform for financial investors aimed at making hedge fund strategies accessible by more people. Some of the strategies they offer are crowdsourced from their own investor community.

Joro.app helps consumer track their personal carbon footprint by translating purchases data (from an API) into carbon tonnes equivalent. The app also has a community component, connecting users with sustainability challenges, classes and other educational tools, along with a social network to communicate with peers to track relative progress (Source: TechCrunch).

As of 2022, about half of all active crypto wallets were part of decentralized apps (dApps) specific to gaming. This drives an enormous amount of financial interaction in conjunction with social gaming. The combined dynamics of community and market for games open numerous possibilities for commerce, learning and others.

http://scenicornot.datasciencelab.co.uk/ crowdsources opinions about the beauty of places in the UK, by asking users to simply rate the beauty of a picture on a website. The data has been combined with geospatial data to evaluate the scenic beauty of places.

Edge computing will enable devices to use information and models built centrally, while maintaining a decentralized data set that isn't shared with any central computer. The result is more private use of powerful AI driven applications.

Low latency networks and edge computing will enable groups of decentralized machines (e.g., drones) to operate in orchestrated and effective fashion, for instance in the case of detecting and countering fire hazard over large expanses, or conversely when operating small devices inside the human body.

Hundreds of thousands of community land trusts exist in the world today in an attempt to make housing more affordable and prevent speculation that can displace local residents, hence enabling them to root and create better community dynamics. Community-owned land is built upon, at their expense, by the house owner. When the owner wants to sell, they can do so within a process that prevents speculation and gives rights of first refusal to neighbors.
Social media app Stocktiwts is in many ways similar to Twitter focuses on stocks, and features private rooms where influencers can guide individual investors.

Social commerce Depop focuses on fashion e.g. apparel, and enables users to contribute to fashion design, as well as to obtain style suggestions. It was acquired by distributed-creativity marketplace Etsy in 2021.

During Formula E (the equivalent of Formula 1 racing with electric cars)  events, the radio discussions between the teams and the pilots are transmitted openly, and other teams can hear them. One of the teams (Virgin, helped by IT services firm Genpact) uses speech to text and then natural language processing to identify the most interesting pieces of intelligence in real time, and take action.

BorrowMyDoggy is an internet platform that connects dog owners with trusted local people who love to look after dogs. From walks, playtime, and overnight stays on holidays, anyone can sign up to BorrowMyDoggy.

Use case: Connect applications through API to form a network
Description: Financial services are notoriously fragmented, which prevents users are providers from benefit from network effects across steps of a financial transaction (e.g. credit assessment, underwriting, balance payment tracking etc). Plaid provides different technology and service providers with APIs that enable that connectivity.

Use case: Provide environmental data through a decentralized web3 platform
Description: dClimate is a transparent, decentralized marketplace where climate data, forecasts, and models are standardized, monetized, and distributed. The marketplace connects data publishers directly with data consumers, making climate data more accessible and reliable. When data providers share data and forecasts with the market it is automatically scored for reliability, which helps consumers to shop for information. In exchange, dClimate creates a simple, direct-to-consumer distribution mechanism to monetize their work. dClimate's base layer is built on Ethereum, and the network leverages Chainlink's leading decentralized oracle network to  facilitate on-chain validation and support for dClimate's governance layer. dClimate starts on day one with a foundation of dozens of terabytes of standardized climate data ready for institutional use and anchor-client Arbol, a leading parametric weather risk platform.

Use case: Enable blockchain incentives for science peer review
Description: The peer review process, which is very costly in terms of time and intellectual investment, not only is not remunerated by the journals but is also not openly recognized by the academic community as a relevant scientific output for a researcher. Therefore, scientific dissemination is affected in timeliness, quality, and fairness. Here, to solve this issue, researchers Trovò and Massari propose a blockchain-based incentive system that rewards scientists for peer-reviewing other scientists' work and that builds up trust and reputation. They designed a privacy-oriented protocol of smart contracts called Ants-Review that allows authors to issue a bounty for open anonymous peer-reviews on Ethereum. If requirements are met, peer-reviews will be accepted and paid by the approver proportionally to their assessed quality. To promote ethical behavior and inclusiveness the system implements a gamified mechanism that allows the whole community to evaluate the peer-reviews and vote for the best ones. Ants Review is an example of decentralized science (DeSci) enabled by Web3 technology.

Use case: Code Web3 software through a collective
Description: dOrg is a decentralized autonomous collective of web3 engineers, designers, and project managers, organized as DAO. They collaborate with projects to advance the web3 stack (DAOs, NFTs, DeFi, dev tools, L2s). https://docs.dorg.tech

Use case: Use social ties to enhance health
Description: Mujin are microcredit associations that increasingly represent a social network for the Japanese elderly, helping them maintain social ties and hence improving their health.

Use case: Use blockchain for real estate registry
Description: In 2018 OpenLaw worked with various Australian lawyers to create an end-to-end real estate transaction platform that is built on the Ethereum blockchain and backed by ERC-721 NFTs. The platform enables the smooth transfer of properties through the minting of NFTs using the Australian government’s centralized records of all official land titles. While the platform is operable and successfully demonstrates the possibility of transferring land and real estate titles through blockchain technology, it would be necessary to first make changes to Australian law for the platform to be widely implemented (source Open Forest Protocol)

Use case: Use NFTs to create forestation registries
Description: Openforestprotocol.org is a community of climate change forestation project operators, validators and funders that uses blockchain technology for its records and transactions. Of particular note is the storage of immutable land-registry forestry records (including validated location, representative imagery) as non-fungible Ethereum blockchain tokens (NFTs).

Use case: Enable ownership of individual trees through NFT
Description: The Corcovado Project aims at enabling the transfer of ownership of individual trees through NFTs, so that their planting can be sponsored in an inexpensive, frictionless manner.  Similar efforts are being performed by Treelion and Treejer.

Use case: Use fashion memes to influence trends
Description: New fashion items, when visible associated with influential people, travel across networks. That propagation is often of the "simple contagion" type, in that even a single exposure to the new items is sufficient to generate demand for it in a new person (see Damon Centola for more). Social media has created a platform for amplification of these signals. The actual value in making the collective behavior of the community more effectively adaptive depends on the influencers (think of second hand fashion vs fast fashion). Fashionable items typically foster a sense of belonging which in itself is an incentive for people in that specific community.

Use case: Propagate social standards for the environment
Description: Similar to fashion trends propagated by influencers, acceptability of visually conspicuous technological innovation such as solar roofs can be favored by "social contagion", that is their increased prevalence in neighborhoods, and especially on houses considered visually attractive or owned by well respected individuals in the community. Adoption acceleration could be achieved by incentivizing nodal early adopters and amplifying their visibility in their community.

Use case: Incentivize community based reforestation with carbon credits
Description: TIST encourages Small Groups of subsistence farmers to improve their local environment and farms by planting and maintaining trees on degraded and/or unused land. Over 128,000 farmers in 4 countries have successfully planted more than 23 million trees and captured over 9 million metric tons of carbon dioxide to date. As the trees grow, carbon captured is quantified and verified and certified greenhouse gas credits are sold in the global carbon market. TIST Farmers receive annual carbon pre-payments for each tree established and and receive 70% of the net profit when credits are sold.

In 2021 NFTs like Bored Ape Yacht Club (10,000 unique images secured by blockchain tech) quickly became cultural icons around which communities of people are formed. That's partially because of the engineered scarcity (an NFT is unique, acting as an identifier of the origin and veracity of the collectible) as well as because of the potential growth in value if the community is successful in attracting demand for others to enter.
Former US president candidate Andrew Young created a community that uses blockchain tokens to organize and fund lobbying campaigns (administered through a DAO) aimed at promoting Web3.

Use case: Support campaigning for controversial personalities through DAO
Description: AssangeDAO, a decentralised autonomous organisation set up to raise money to cover the fees and publicity campaigns towards Julian Assange’s release, collected over millions ETH in mere days, in 2022.

DrivenData, in collaboration with HeroX, hosted in 2022 a crowdsourcing competition on behalf of NASA: Mars Spectrometry, Detect Evidence for Past Habitability. The challenge, which offers a $30,000 prize purse, seeks innovative methods to automatically help analyze and interpret evolved gas analysis-mass spectrometry data related to Mars exploration. This data is from geological samples of scientific interest to better understand the planet's potential signs of past habitability.

Use case: Democratize social commerce for India and the global South
Description: Founded in 2018, DealShare operates a social commerce platform of curated products sourced from multiple suppliers, including large manufacturers, local brands, and distributors at highly competitive prices. It lists products across categories like groceries, FMCG, perishable goods, personal care, fashion, and others. DealShare is serving customers in more than 100 Indian cities and towns where the likes of Amazon and Flipkart have made little to no inroad. The startup aims to democratize online shopping for Bharat users with unmatched service and experience by developing innovative products and tech solutions. This will be supported by building their teams across the country and hiring new tech talent at all levels. Additionally, DealShare is also planning to expand to several international markets e.g. the Middle East.

Use case: Use eSports and Multiplayer video games to attract millions
Description: Better network connectivity and faster processors have led to the emergence of massive global networks of players, part of them becoming professionals and influencers who tap into actual and lucrative markets. League of Legends is an example. The dynamics of the games, including novel strategies, are integral part of the entertainment, the training of the respective AI, and the future development of the games

Shares is an investment app and social community for any investor to make trades, manage their portfolio, and discuss opportunities with friends. With Shares, family, friends and seasoned investors can invest together, sharing knowledge and experience to inspire long-term growth in their investments.
Litterati.org and OpenLitterMap engage communities by making media and geospatial data easily available, and gamifying the cleanup efforts

Use case: Gamify real time flooding information for Zambezi river
Description: Players earn game currency by reporting the water level, weather, and other real-time information about their local area. They can earn more by placing bets about future conditions.This gathers real time information but also involves local residents in predictions to train the ability to prepare for future flooding events and to trust models. (source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Assess mobile phone sensors magnetic accuracy
Description: Crowdsourced measurement of magnetism through personal smartphones, in order to ascertain the quality of those devices for magnetism mapping.

Use case: Use financial networks for emergency foreign policy
Description: On the eve of Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the response from many Western countries and their allies was to enlist the financial institutions in restricting the flow of money so that specific Russian interests were impacted through peaceful means. Financial flows, from banks to crypto, have a systemic impact as they prevent the redistribution of resources across parts of the network (in this case, Russian oligarchs networks).

Use case: Use SMS to engage the public
Description: Interactive Text’s web platform "sends, receives, and analyzes text messages so you can reach the people you serve with the technology already in their pocket, 24/7."

Use case: Crowdsource the annotation of a citizen discourse corpus
Description: Granddebat.fr offers to the public the ability to weigh in on many social issues, by providing plain-text answers. To help the analysis, this project enlists the help of thousands of people who tag the contributions.

Use case: Use Web3 for distributed machine learning processing
Description: Sentient network attempts to build a distributed global computer with the participant nodes providing a portion of their hardware resources for artificial intelligence computations. Each node will determine what allocation of its resources it wishes to make available to the network for computations, and receive the corresponding rewards. Status as of 2022 was unclear

CureAccelerator supports “proof of concept” research repurposing drugs, devices and nutriceuticals already approved for human use. On CureAccelerator, funders have direct access to repurposing research, researchers can post ideas and connect with peers and funding, and clinicians can contribute their experience of off-label use in need of validation.

Use case: Improve the synergy between rare-disease associations
Description: EURORDIS seeks to improve the quality of life of people living with rare diseases in Europe through advocacy at the European level, support for research and medicines development, facilitating networking amongst patient groups, raising awareness, and many other actions designed to reduce the impact of rare diseases on the lives of patients and family. Linked to orpha.net

Use case: Combine health and social care tracking
Description: "Our team standardizes how health and social care providers communicate and track outcomes together. We align all stakeholders from healthcare, government, and the community around a shared goal to improve health. Our proven infrastructure provides both a person-centered care coordination platform and a hands-on community engagement process; we work hand-in-hand with communities to ensure services are seamlessly delivered to the people who need them most."
OrganJet provides an information service, as well as options for timely and affordable air transport, for patients who are multi-listed or distant listed for organ transplants in the U.S.
The crowdEEG app is a collaborative annotation tool that enables groups of experts or non-expert crowds to perform feature detection or high level classification tasks on medical time series data.
A team of fact checkers prioritizes statement made by influential sources and posts the assessment online, ready to be picked up and shared by social media and other information platforms on the web.

Use case: Simplify and incentivize the acquisition of carbon-abatement assets
Description: The Climate Collective is a community of companies tokenizing natural assets acquisition. Celo blockchain stablecoins are backed in part by tokenized carbon-abating natural assets as collateral. As the demand for the coins increases, Celo will buy more natural assets. Celo is an environmentally friendly proof-of-stake blockchain platform with native stablecoins that are backed by a basket of crypto assets. By allocating a fraction of these assets to natural capital, the reserve can create an incentive mechanism that aligns demand for stablecoins with the protection of natural capital. This mechanism acts as a large-scale carbon sink. As currency demand increases, the reserve programmatically preserves rainforests and other carbon sequestering assets. This provides for a monetary system in which any economic growth—any increase in money in circulation—would lead to a preservation and regeneration of natural resources.
Kobo360, a sort of Uber for freight, has helped Nigerian truck drivers to improve a notoriously inefficient, opaque and prone-to-corruption market

Use case: Enable a WiFi network through blockchain
Description: Blockchain based Helium.com enables a crowdsourced WiFi network, where users add software to their router and use Helium's cryptocurrency as an incentive and governance mechanism.

Use case: Motivate and enable users to create content
Description: In mid-2020, in the wake of the controversy about TikTok, Facebook moved swiftly to offer financial incentives to TikTok creators with millions of followers, to encourage them to move to Facebook’s Reels; TikTok countered this move with a US $300 million “creative fund” aimed at highly popular creators. TikTok is also an interesting example on how to motivate a community of creators, by making future success on one’s creation less dependent on past successes (the “old money effect” in social media) and more dependent on the actual interest of the community members in the current creation.
In Wikipedia, mastery is a strong driver for community members’ efforts.

Use case: Use feeling of "Flow" as a performance booster
Description: Flow, the concept developed by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi 117 refers to the positive experience felt by people who are absorbed in an activity they master. The restaurant McDonald’s famously redesigned its kitchen layout and standard operating procedures to enable employees to achieve a certain level of collective flow. In that respect, Significant workflow in large enterprises, starting from early industrial revolution restructuring of assembly line, had some “group flow and mastery” at its root.

Energized, connected systems already exist - think of the success of things like Kaggle.com, TopCoder or Kickstarter that combine both intrinsic (mastery, fame) with extrinsic (monetary prizes, often however, mostly a reinforcement of the intrinsic motivation).

A rich source of energy is the information exhaust which can amplify an individual’s contribution. Companies like Waze understand that well. Waze offers a very balanced ratio between what it gives (guidance enriched by fellow travelers’ actions) and what it asks for (the GPS coordinates of your telephone, and the occasional action to flag an issue on the road).

Use case: Use network based incentives to solve problems
Description: In the DARPA “red balloon challenge”, participating teams competed to find the location of ten red balloons released randomly over a very large territory across the United States. The winning team, an MIT group, successfully used incentives to stimulate participation of thousands of people, not unlike methods used in multi-level marketing.

Use case: Allocate time and money to employee projects
Description: CultivateLabs enables companies to give people some time and budget to allocate, in order to crowdfund promising ideas. In some respect this is similar to early prediction markets that were dispensing fictional money to observe which bets employees would take – except that in this case, the time and/or money are real and will be effectively allocated once the employee has made that decision, and the candidate project has achieved a minimum funding level to be approved and funded.

In response to the significant market control of established online companies such as Google, new intermediaries (such as Substack, or its not-for-profit counterpart ghost.org, for newsletter creators) are emerging to provide better incentives to creators.
American crowdfunding platform, covering everything from celebration to expensive cures.
Grantfortheweb.org is notable in its mission as “a fund for the development of open, fair and inclusive standards and innovation in web monetization”.

Kickstarter's structure allows people with specific interests (e.g. art, fashion, consumer electronics, etc) to provide monetary support for what they believe are worthy causes. In return, they receive some extrinsic reward (the finished product) but mostly a strong intrinsic reward, such as “insider” information about the progress of the project. Kickstarter has made the matching of supply and demand for monetary incentive relatively frictionless, so funders aren’t just wealthy patrons of the arts. And because the funders receive strong intrinsic incentives, it enables Significant more risk taking on the part of the entrepreneur – as well as the funding of endeavors that don’t have strong monetary output.
Online sweepstakes
Creator crowdfunding.

In response to the significant market control of established online companies such as Google, new intermediaries (such as Substack, or its not-for-profit counterpart ghost.org, for newsletter creators) are emerging to provide better incentives to creators.
There are new solutions for the generation of granular payment streams from the users to the providers, e.g. those proposed by open-source Webmonetization.org and its web-monetization wallets.
Swiss platform for funding inventors.

Use case: Mechanisms for frictionless distribution of incentives
Description: 0x.org allows for the exchange of tokens enabling the secure allocation of reward to distributed workforces (both human and machines).

"Crowdfund Capital Advisors (CCA) delivers strategic insights to government agencies, financial institutions, regulators and multilateral organizations seeking to both create and implement innovative strategies to utilize crowdfund investing (CFI) technologies to drive innovation, job creation and entrepreneurship."

Use case: Enable crowdfunding venture rounds through platform
Description: Wefunder and StartEngine are platforms for investing in startups and small businesses.

Harnesses the ability of the market to be rewarded for providing insight, not just transactions. For instance, Gnosis.pm prediction markets conditional tokens (blockchain based), enable more precise risk-adjusted pricing and matching demand with supply of predictions, including the ability to predict, trade, and hold funds.

Use case: Use citizen Observatories projects to monitor agricultural developments
Description: Expanding on GEOSS (Global Earth Observation System of Systems), the Citizen Observatories projects are funded by the European Union. One of them is GROW (soil-moisture citizen observatory) aimed at climate change and including scientists, NGOs, communities and individuals. Computer vision sifts through mixed-source (people, machines) imagery from both people and machines to enable better agricultural decisions at OneSoil.ai.

For over a decade, OpenStreetMap's thousands of volunteers have toiled to provide an open source alternative to commercial geo-mapping, further annotating and correcting computer-vision-detected terrain. Additional uses of this networked intelligence include rapid re- mapping of areas impacted by natural disasters.

Use case: Use bots for facilitation of democratic debate
Description: Apptivism.org uses custom-built bots to engage constituencies and collect their feedback.

Identifying the words that describe the space being searched (the semantic network that delineates ontologies e.g. words that are ideally MECE - mutually exclusive and hopefully collectively exhaustive) can be done either heuristically by asking experts to map out the words and clustering them in groups, or even analytically by extracting so-called “entities” by using R or Python NLTK - or more specialized entity visualizers like DisplaCy - to identify words recurrence in typical content.

Kaggle, the data science contest community, was used during the COVID-19 pandemic to write natural language processing algorithms helping scientists interpret insights emerging from research done around the world.

Bridgit.io (in alpha version as of January 2020) enables people to annotate web objects to manually create knowledge graphs. An additional possible use of some of these technologies and the related network intelligence is fact checking

Use case: Annotate text to provide better metadata
Description: Human curators can also use web text annotations tools, like getMemex.com, effectively appending metadata to text parcels of browsing history, in a way that’s somewhat like what Amazon Kindle allows to do on kindle-format books.

A more collaborative approach to web bookmarking is taken by hypothes.is, that enables communities (for instance, academics, teachers, publishers or journalists) to tag and annotate documents, and discuss them online – providing not only an information feeder but the beginning of a collaboration platform.
Credentials as an incentive: Methods like Lean Six Sigma, leverage mastery through publicly-recognized credentials to keep people going.

Use case: Incentivize peer to peer media resource sharing
Description: Open source music-sharing application Napster, before shutting its doors crushed by the legal implications of its own success, showed the power of providing simple incentives (“listen to more music for free”) with a strong web-based collaboration platform.

Use case: Issue fan crypto tokens by football clubs as additional financing and governance
Description: PSG as well as other clubs (e.g. AC Milan) are issuing cryptocurrency tokens that increase in value as the team's popularity increases. As an example, Lionel Messi's acquisition by PSG was partially paid in crypto tokens. Tokens also provide some voting rights to fans for minor decisions.
Google AdWords has incentivized people monetarily to post novel (or simply attractive) content for many years with cash payments.

Can ecosystems decide? Ecosystems benefit from the natural experiments that happen in loosely connected parts of the network and can provide significant creativity as well as resiliency. They’re however harder to align and control. Nature effectively chooses, over time, based on alternatives created by mutations of genes and the environment; it expresses those genes in the short term through epigenetics (for instance metabolic changes in response to a famine, transmitted to the next generation); and mutations of RNA seem to show longer-term "memory" of the reaction to biological event (such as in the case of mounting a defense to a bacteria)

Use case: Collect information and help employees collaborate
Description: In many companies, the foundation of a collective knowledge feeder already exists through the convergence of three things: electronic communications, especially email and more recent collaboration environments like Slack or Microsoft Teams or, in open communities, tools like Circle; organizational structures that include subject matter expert s, e.g. practice leaders in consulting firms; and pervasive information feeds fueled by the explosion of internet-based knowledge sharing from social media to specifically curated knowledge feeds.

Use case: Enable an asynchronous buildup of ideas by groups of people
Description: Prior to the creation of email, it was hard for groups of people to build on each other’s thoughts unless they were in the same place, or on the same telephone call. When they did, for instance through scientific societies, progress was slow. Email was the first tool to enable an asynchronous buildup of ideas. Despite its limitations, it is still the workhorse of remote, asynchronous collaboration. An estimated 230 billion emails are exchanged every day. And email is still evolving. Consider recent development such as the ability to show conversations in threads, the auto-classification of email types, and Gmail’s automatic reply suggestions. Bolt-ons such as Superhuman. And the weaving of email with workflow such as Sedna. All are examples of attempts to use machines to simplify human’s email work. Most innovative companies use these tools heavily and rely comparatively less on email.
Humans verify the quality of machine insight / output.
Moderation of inappropriate web content.
Crowdsourced sensor data used by machines.

Agile methods have become standard for innovation execution in technology organizations. In Agile, “pods” or “squads” (i.e. small productive units) exist, where a product owner collaborates with developers and subject matter experts who complement each other, all orchestrated by a scrum master. They’re collectively able to provide output with other pods’, and jointly contribute to the final product.

Agile has spawned additional organizational ideas like IT analyst Gartner “fusion teams” (“cross-functional teams that use data and technology to achieve business outcomes”). Open source movements like Linux routinely apply community-based, collective skills to software code reviews. The combination of these organizational innovations has changed the world.

Use case: Cross sell of financial products across siloed product groups through "invisible" network employees
Description: A cohort of mid-tier employees was instrumental in the cross-selling of financial products in an investment banking firm, by enabling smaller transactions across different (and otherwise siloed) product groups and effectively serving as integrators across org chart divides. Without dedicated support and recognition, many of these valuable staff members were leaving the firm. Once their role was highlighted, incentives and support structure were put in place and the overall organization benefited.

Community with large number of quantitatively skilled analysts enabling crowdsourced data science, running competitions. Closed in 2020, and assets were transferred to low-fee financial trading platform Robinhood.

“Folding at Home” uses the federated computing power of thousands of home devices to process computationally hard tasks (especially in the field of biology). Other similar initiatives also exist using the same infrastructural concept e.g. Einstein@home (spinning neutron stars' signals), MilkyWay@home (3D galaxy pictures), Rosetta@home (protein structure predictions), Stardust@home (interstellar dust impact) and LHC@home (particle accelerator data).
Craigslist or eBay showed the potential of giving people the ability to trade outside of more- hierarchical retail environments.
WhatsApp and similar support groups that form around communities of disenfranchised and abused expatriate workers from poor countries.

Description: Specialized platform for crowdsourcing

Use case: Enable a microwork platform for gig workers
Description: Amazon Turk identifies people that provide help for specific purposes, and enables them to use open, purpose-built platforms. It has been used for micro-tasks (say, labeling pictures) for more than a decade.

Description: CrowdFlower is a leading public provider of microwork platforms. Crowdsourcing however depends on generally strict workflows, that lend themselves less well to exploration. In many respects, they mostly do a sense and remember, and some simple “decide” collective cognitive job.
Quantopian's contests, populated by thousands of “quants” from various fields, aim at creating new, and radically diverse, financial markets trading algorithms.

Like trade conferences and a plethora of special-interest local chapters, this is an example of a place where networks can be identified. If they leave an “internet breadcrumb trail”, they can typically be detected and they can be used to create local, in-person meetups

Use case: Establish rules to enable efficient distributed collaboration
Description: Amazon’s “two- pizza principle”, whereby agile teams’ meetings can’t be bigger than what two pizzas can feed, is an attempt to communicate through a simple meme some very important norms that have bearings on a system’s effectiveness and efficiency. It favors continuous experimentation through independent and scrappy teams. This allows for the work of many, loosely coordinated teams to stay focused and edgy and experiment enough so that some of them will hit big results at some point – cost-effectively. Similar considerations apply to companies whose meetings participations are bloated, especially when virtual meetings make large meetings very easy to set up.
Slack app “random coffee” pairs up network members in a randomized fashion.

Some software companies that specialize in collaboration technology, like Slack, help peripheral nodes connect into a network. For instance, a Slack add-on called Donut proactively forces serendipitous or programmatic connection between people.
Icebreaker - Microsoft Office 365 bot that pairs up network members (developers) in a randomized fahion.

MIT’s Center for Collective intelligence released an open source code base and concept called Minglr that focuses on facilitating impromptu synchronous interactions between people who want to talk to each other – using some of the same principles that matchmaking apps like Tinder have perfected, and applying them to replicating “watercooler” conversations.
Technology build on Microsoft Office 365 and Worplace Analytics promoting the targeted connection between people (as opposed to standard randomization algorithms)
Slack functionality Sparkly attempts to connect network newcomers to others with similar interests.

Every big collective effort, from Wikipedia to Linux, has always walked a tightrope around allocating credit to many contributors while recognizing the leadership of central nodes. Successful networks ultimately avoid concentrating rewards or glorifying one person.

In 2016, Mexico City “open- sourced” PublicLab input to their city’s constitution, where contributions from hundreds of thousands of people were translated into legal language by a central committee. Madrid are experimenting along the same lines, as is Reykjavik with its Better Reykjavik program.
After the BP oil spill on the US Gulf Coast in 2010 triggered a networked intelligence response, the resulting platform, PublicLab.org, has been adapted and used elsewhere in the world.

A marketplace of learning-by-doing opportunities allows learners to consolidate memorization of the learning curriculum by executing small projects in mostly virtual settings. They leverage Microsoft Office 365 including Teams, as well as the core functionality of a Learning Experience Platform (Edcast). The latter also facilitates collaboration by enabling fluid feedback from the learners on specific parts of the curriculum.

Description: Software in the “collaborative workspace management” attempt to streamline somewhat repetitive and even project-based work that doesn’t fit squarely in a traditional workflow – examples in that space include Wrike, Workfront, Asana, Hive, Unito, Taskade, and Basecamp, as well as other enterprise social media

Stablecoins seek to maintain a constant value of a token relative to some asset, most commonly the U.S. dollar or other major fiat currency. Non-custodial stablecoins function as DeFi services themselves. Custodial stablecoins are centralized but may be incorporated into DeFi services. An example is DAI (governed by MakerDAO) based on Ethereum.

Exchanges allow users to trade one digital asset for another. DeFi exchanges avoid taking custody of user assets, either through a decentralized order book or by matching orders and setting prices algorithmically. Uniswap and SushiSwap are examples.

Credit involves the creation of time-limited interest-bearing instruments, which must be repaid at maturity, and the matching of lenders and borrowers to issue those instruments. Flash loans are an example, enabling borrowing from decentralized protocols such as Aave and dYdX. Another example is Compound “a money market protocol that lets users instantly lend to or borrow from a pool of assets in a smart contract”

Derivatives are synthetic financial instruments whose value is based on a function of an underlying asset or group of assets. Common examples are futures and options, which reference the value of an asset at some time in the future. An example is Synthetix, a synthetic asset issuance protocol built on Ethereum.

Insurance provides protection against risks by trading the payment of a guaranteed small premium for the possibility of collecting a large payout in the event of a covered scenario. Asset management seeks to maximize the value of an asset portfolio based on risk preferences, time horizons, diversification, or other conditions. An example is NexusMutual which offers smart contract insurance cover, for protection against a smart contract bug, in the UK.

Use case: Perform financial Asset Management through DeFi
Description: Asset management seeks to maximize the value of an asset portfolio based on risk preferences, time horizons, diversification, or other conditions. An example is Set Protocol, a decentralized portfolio management protocol enabling users to create a token that represents a fully collateralized portfolio of other digital assets, including Bitcoin, Ethereum, and stablecoins.

The firm collaborates with business angels, corporate finance specialists and venture capital companies to raise capital. Companisto offers a sectorial approach focused on information technology, software, consumer products, e-commerce, social media and energy sectors. (Source: Pitchbook) Similar mechanisms are at play at Republic.io, Ourcrowd, Seedatthetable.

Description: Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) llama helps manage treasury, as does Parcel which also supports payouts;

Description: According to Jeff Hawkins' "Thousand Brains" theory, the brain does not contain one model of the world; it contains thousands of complementary models for everything we know. The models vote together to produce our singular perception.

Use case: Label datasets for AI by frontline responders, human-in-the-loop technology development
Description: Ensuring human oversight of algorithms after deployment can help to identify and correct these errors in a timely manner. For this project, a group of volunteers from the Montgomery County Community Emergency Response Team (MCERT) helped to check and correct labels assigned by the AI classifier. This participatory approach, known as human-in-the-loop, was used to verify the classifications being made by the system and correct any mistakes in real time. The process also resulted in a novel image dataset with expert labels of damage to further train the algorithm and improve its accuracy during future deployments.During the two-week period that followed the landfall of Hurricane Dorian, the system was deployed to collect and filter social media images. Approximately 160,000 images were tagged as relevant by the system, with ~26,000 of these containing some damage content. All images that the system ranked as severe or mild were sent for human validation. Using a dedicated web-interface for microtasking to support humanitarian efforts, local domain experts from MCERT examined this evolving sample, performing a two-stage verification. They first checked if the image contained damage content and then assigned a severity level based on a predetermined taxonomy. The research team also developed a detailed tutorial to ensure that all labellers were approaching the task in a consistent manner. The corrections made by the community responders helped to identify common types of errors made by the algorithm. For example, the AI system struggled with images taken from afar or in low-light and poor resolution settings. Isolating this weakness helped the technical team to develop targeted improvements and the response teams to better understand the potential added value of the AI tool for their operations during crisis response. (Source: Nesta UK)

Ecological restoration initiatives have often ignored the role of indigenous people and local groups in maintaining ecosystems and failed to account for the local history and political context. In Mazvihwa Communal Area, Zimbabwe, there are ongoing land management problems where woodland grazing areas are increasingly being converted to cropland. After the model was finalised, the Muonde team held workshops with local traditional authorities, including the local Chief, the ward head (machinda), and the individual village heads (sabhuku). In these workshops, they used the model to visualise different actions and resulting impacts, which helped local stakeholders to discuss land management practices, past actions that had resulted in drought and the challenges associated with their agro-pastoral system. These discussions led to policy changes that allowed the reuse of fallow fields for farming. Months after these workshops, the community members reported that the model helped them realise the interaction between their different behaviours, understand the systemic drivers in the ecosystem and to take responsibility for the collective action that was necessary to improve outcomes. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Enable participatory AI modeling in healthcare
Description:
Sepsis Watch is a sepsis detection and management platform that uses deep learning to predict the likelihood of a patient developing sepsis. It was co-created by a multidisciplinary team that included hospital staff and a technical team to improve the clinical outcomes associated with sepsis, which was a major issue for the local hospital. Machine learning technologies are increasingly being developed for healthcare settings. These models are often created by engineering teams outside of the clinical environment and implementation decisions are made at the leadership level, rather than with the involvement of clinicians or nurses who are expected to use and integrate the tool into their existing workflows. Research has also suggested that machine learning models in healthcare have poor generalisability. This means their performance suffers when they are used in real-world settings where the local data follows
statistically different patterns to the datasets they were trained on. The Sepsis Watch model was created in close collaboration with clinicians over two and a half years, with participation integrated throughout the AI development pipeline. Throughout the process the team placed a strong emphasis on developing trust between the individuals involved and also in the technology solution. The thirty month co-design process for Sepsis Watch eventually resulted in its integration into the clinical setting. This process resulted in securing institutional buy-in and retaining ownership over decision making among frontline staff. Doctors and nurses developed new processes for decision making that made use of the tool alongside their expertise. As the frontline users of Sepsis Watch, nurses also reported that the tool helped them expand their professional skills. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Enable participatory AI modeling for refugee displacement prediction
Description: In 2017 frontline workers in Dollo Ado in Ethiopia appealed to the UNHCR Innovation Service to design an algorithm that would help them to better predict the flows of displaced people in order to better plan for and manage their arrival. The technical team developing the AI solution spent many months in Dollo Ado to better understand the context for which they were developing the algorithm. They conducted detailed interviews with both frontline workers and displaced Somalis to better understand the specific factors associated with migration in the region. This allowed them to isolate ten core variables to focus on for the first iteration of the predictive model. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Enable participatory modeling for a food donation matching algorithm
Description: 412 Food Rescue provides a ‘food rescue’ service that matches expiring food from donating organisations such as grocery stores with recipient organisations. Its success relies on efficient matching between donations and recipients as well as a volunteer network to transport the packages. They developed a participatory framework known as WeBuildAI to model the preferences of different stakeholders involved in the service and ultimately satisfy their needs and priorities. For example, if the algorithm optimised efficiency, volunteers would have shorter driving times and the areas closest to donating organisations would receive a disproportionate share of donations. Prioritising equity of distribution on the other hand could make it more difficult to recruit and retain volunteers. By involving groups who prioritised efficiency or equity to varying degrees in the algorithm design, the researchers hoped that all of the participants would continue engaging with the service and that the distribution of donations would be more equitable. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case:
Model behaviours and
interventions for crisis mitigation, Modelling
behaviours and interventions for crisis recovery
Description: Natural resource ecosystems (e.g. forest, agricultural, land-use management, water) are complex to model and understand because they are affected by a wide range of factors including both environmental and human behaviours. Knowledge related to ecosystems and the factors that impact them is distributed between numerous stakeholders, such as scientists, local residents and frontline managers, who often have distinct (and sometimes competing) interests. This makesit difficult to understand the short- and longterm’ impacts of environment and resource management decisions, and to tackle resource issues that require collective decision making and agreement. In the case of the Sequía Project in Uruguay, local farmers were struggling to identify and plan adaptation strategies in the face of severe drought. What is the CCI solution? Companion modelling uses Agent BasedModels (ABMs) and role-playing games to help represent and simulate socio-economic systems for natural resource management.  This participatory approach uses the collective intelligence of a wide range of stakeholders to design and implement ABMs, and features interactive simulations enabling participating stakeholders to test different scenarios and outcomes. How is it being done?The underlying concept of companion modelling is to use role-playing games to enable stakeholders to interact with a model or simulation of a specified resource ecosystem, and to modify the behaviour of various agents in order to understand the impact of different uses of resources. Over a series of workshops with stakeholders, the model is specified and explored while participants discuss the implications of various management decisions. A companion modelling approach is a participatory and iterative process whereby stakeholders are involved in the definition and design of the questions, models, simulations and outputs. In turn, it is possible to collectively explore scenarios to better understand how a desired situation may be reached. The Sequía project used Cormas, a simulation computer programme that uses ABMs. It is an open-source platform used by environmental resource researchers internationally to facilitate the design, monitoring and analysis  f simulation scenarios. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Crowdsource database and foster community for environmental restoration
Description: Restor is a science-based open data platform to support and connect the global restoration movement, accelerating the global restoration movement by connecting everyone, everywhere to local restoration. Restor connects people to scientific data, supply chains, funding, and each other to increase the impact, scale, and sustainability of restoration efforts. Participants can Analyse restoration potential for any area anywhere, Monitor and manage all their restoration projects in one place, Share projects to show progress and support the movement, and Connect with the movement (e.g. Explore sites locally and globally, Find potential partners doing similar work, Search using a range of scientific and social filters, Share contact information to connect directly with other users.)

Apple AppStore's creates incentives and standards for developers, hence generating emergent optimization dynamics that result in competitive strength. Apple only touches the system's "high-leverage" points (e.g. policies, security, payment, performance), and the system then largely optimizes itself.

Microsoft has established a strong market "ecosystem" through its technical and commercial platform for developers who use their products. They support the commercialization thanks to the cross-selling those developers can do on the back of Microsoft's market presence. They also control some important high-leverage points of the system, such as security and policies standards to help with trust and control, and collaboration through GitHub. They also support the cybersecurity layer. The result is an emerging, intelligent adaptation of the network.

Amazon has established a strong market "ecosystem" that leverages its supply chain platform, arguably one of the most sophisticated and commercially powerful in the world. They control some high-leverage points in the system, such as pricing, client engagement, logistics policies. The result is emerging network intelligence whose outcomes are continuous adaptation and, so far, market success.

Use case: Create network effect for consumers and e-commerce
Description: Tencent's subsidiaries have created significant network dynamics across connecting people, giving them incentives to collaborate, and providing an environment where it is safe (or at least it is perceived to be safe, within sometime-politicized boundaries) to do so.

Use case: Use real-life driving to improve autonomous driving
Description: Tesla is capturing network dynamics thanks to its collection of data from real-life driving, that helps improving autonomous-driving algorithms. Irrespective of when it will reach full autonomous driving level, Tesla is able to enhance the lower levels thanks to its superior access to voluminous and varied data, as well as clear AI-algorithm sophistication. The emergent network dynamics are foundational to Tesla's value.

Use case: Harness the models of thousands of data scientists for hedge funds
Description: Numerai serves up obfuscated data (homomorphic encryption) to over 7,000 data scientists who feed back AI models to predict the stock market, and get paid in digital currencies when the trades are successful. It aims at creating meta models by crowdsourcing models that predict stock market dynamics better.
The Openinsulin.org is “working to develop the first practical, small-scale, community-centered model for insulin production to make insulin accessible to all”.

Use case: Optimize allocation of resources (people and machines' time...) to tasks
Description: Where appropriate and possible allocate work deliberately, for instance with a sort of ticketing system whose algorithm matches resources with tasks. It is also possible for contributors to decide where to work out of the open tasks. In the examples Wikipedia and Linux, for instance, the latter option is adopted, but contributions are subjugated to contributors having the right credentials.

Colony.io attempts to create a protocol for interoperability between an emerging set of technologies based on Ethereum, for instance, and is focused on the management of the human resources – in contrast to Augur (predictions), golem.network (distributed computing power) and 0x.org (exchange of tokens).
Long-form text editors allow contributions from multiple authorized users.

Description: Using humans to label data that then is served up to artificial intelligence algorithms

Description: Hyperconnectivity and the ability to inventory and quality-control millions of people at minimal marginal cost has changed its dynamics radically, effectively surfacing the cognitive surplus of millions of people and reshaping many jobs. Platforms have in many respects created the current “gig economy” movement, and they increasingly show specialization of roles where very specific expertise is harnessed in a way that wasn’t possible before – an idea first publicized by MIT’s Malone and colleagues in 2011

Focused on consultation, engagement and co-creation with citizens to invigorate participation in democratic and public action.

Description: Idea management platforms are built to streamline and optimize the otherwise messy flow of idea input and refinement. Description: Innocentive is one of the most established communities, and is famously behind Significant of NASA’s open innovation efforts. Geniuslink, ideated by General Electric shares some of the same tenets. MIT Solve, on the other hand, is a competition that seeks community-based innovation that can enable inclusion and shared prosperity. Other examples include MIT's FUtures CoLab, OpenIdeo, Pixel UK (ideated by Deloitte), and Polyplexus (developed by DARPA, whicih is also known as being at the inception of the original internet protocol), whcih combines open-innovation collaboration with Delphi-style expert-community predictions.

An organizational construct used by Amnesty International which uses its volunteers in Amnesty Decoders, for instance in Decode Darfur which asked participants to identify destroyed areas in the settlements of Darfur using satellite images. Salient characteristics of Amnestty Decoders are: a) annotated data sets created by crowds; b) clustering of human language inputs; c) automated translations; d) automated classification of visual objects. A specific use case is "Troll Patrol" that targets social media misinformation and obfuscation.
The Phylo DNA puzzle (from Canada’ McGill and some Canadian governmental agencies), through which large numbers of people identify alignments in clusters of genetic data.

Who / What: Skype, Cisco Webex, Adobe Connect, Citrix GoToMeeting, Google Hangouts, BlueJeans, Zoom, Around, Fuze, Lifesize, Loom, Owl, Starleaf, TechSmith, Hopin
Description: Unified communications are an obvious collaboration environment, specifically catering for synchronous or near-real-time (e.g. chat) interactions.  These interactions are important because many people tend to be more productive and creative when they can bounce off thoughts with each other synchronously (mirror neurons may have something to do with it). This technology space has seen significant advances in the last decade, starting with the disruption that Skype introduced into the telecom industry, but also with entrants competing successfully. The recent coronavirus emergency boosted the adoption of these tools, especially as the cloud- based version of them was already extensively used in organizations, enabling scalability while maintaining an appropriate level of security.

Use case: Facilitate logistics of scheduling synchronous collaboration
Description: Companies like doodle.ai and X.ai have started attacking the problem to make the user experience a lot more intuitive (for instance using email’s natural language). Other applications that integrate with Microsoft Outlook, and Microsoft themselves are actively working at the problem, to eliminate the labor-intensive work of finding common slots. Limitations due to information security restrictions will likely soon be resolved, and the only constraint will be user awareness. It is probable that one of the most useful applications of AI will then be the work of finding common slots that minimize the inconvenience for all participants.

Description: The Wild is possibly the first current example of fully collaborative 3D models where people can work together in a virtual space to gain insight on anything from architecture to product design. Real time, immersive collaboration holds the promise of providing a three-dimensional canvas, and an emotional immediacy that traditional virtual spaces don’t have.

Prediction platforms that combine the opinion of people have been around since the early 2000s, for instance in the form of “prediction markets”177 where individuals can “bet” on specific outcomes (like the future trend in a market or the success of a new product) and the platform’s algorithms combine and weigh the results. Companies like Eli Lilly, IBM and Google have all used them extensively in the past to obtain “signals” to improve their development of new solutions. IBM’s alphaWorks used to track downloads of “alpha” (i.e. very early release) solution to predict future demand. Eli Lilly identified many MDs and PhDs who proved extremely far sighted in predicting future drug’s commercial performance.
